bioghist.p: Samuel Stehman Haldeman (1812-1880) was an American naturalist and philologist. In 1851 he was appointed Professor of the Natural Sciences at the University of Pennsylvania. In 1855 he joined the faculty of Delaware College but in 1868, he returned to the University of Pennsylvania as the first chair of its Comparative Philology department, remaining at the University until his death. Haldeman published and lectured on a variety of topics, including malacology, orthography, geology, philology, and chemistry.

scopecontent.p: The collection consists primarily of Haldeman's correspondence, 1840-1880. Topics include philology, phonography, ethnology, natural history, and archaeology. Notable correspondents include William Wagner, Richard Owen, Noah Webster, Melvil Dewey, and C. & G. Merriam. The collection also includes invitations to lectures at the University of Pennsylvania, and a small amount of correspondence from the University relating to Haldeman's appointments to professorships in Comparative Philology and Natural History.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
